name: 1575_A. Another Sorting Problem
description:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4
repair_prompt:
Andi and Budi were tasked with arranging their bookshelf containing n books. Each book is represented by a book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Andi and Budi were tasked with arranging their bookshelf containing n books. Each book is represented by a book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n. Each book has a title made up of exactly m letters. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4

Andi and Budi were tasked with arranging their bookshelf containing n books, each book is represented by a book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending. Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly. A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:   * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b;   * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA

BB
BA
AZ

completion:
def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple where odd-indexed characters are sorted ascendingly
    # and even-indexed characters are sorted descendingly
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom sort key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()
completions:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def custom_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a tuple of characters with the custom sorting logic
        # Odd-indexed positions (1-based) are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
        return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    books.sort(key=custom_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted books
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in books]
    
    # Print the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a tuple of characters with the custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (ord(title[i]) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(title[i]))
            for i in range(m)
        )
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    def custom_key(title):
        # Create a tuple of characters with odd positions as is and even positions negated

    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom key

# [core concept]
    'asc-desc-ending order'
    Explanation: This is a custom sorting order where odd-indexed characters in the book titles are sorted in ascending lexicographical order, and even-indexed characters are sorted in descending lexicographical order.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'odd-indexed', 'even-indexed'
    Explanation: Odd-indexed refers to characters at positions 1, 3, 5, etc., while even-indexed refers to characters at positions 2, 4, 6, etc. In the context of sorting, this means that characters at odd positions are compared in ascending order, and characters at even positions are compared in descending order.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    The steps involving the custom comparator function and sorting should be implemented simultaneously. Specifically, the implementation of the custom comparator function and its use in sorting the list of book titles should be done in one code block to ensure the sorting logic is applied correctly.

# [edge case]
    1. Input: 1 1 \n A
       Output: 1
       Explanation: With only one book title, the order remains the same.
    2. Input: 2 2 \n AA \n AB
       Output: 1 2
       Explanation: Both titles have the same first character, but the second character in 'AA' is lexicographically earlier than in 'AB' when considering even-indexed descending order.
    3. Input: 3 3 \n ABC \n ACB \n BAC
       Output: 2 1 3
       Explanation: The first differing position for 'ABC' and 'ACB' is the second character, where 'C' (in 'ACB') is later than 'B' (in 'ABC') in descending order. 'BAC' comes last because 'B' is later than 'A' in ascending order.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The custom comparator function inherently handles these cases by applying the asc-desc-ending order logic consistently across all book titles.

    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()

    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def custom_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a tuple of characters with the custom sorting logic
        # Odd-indexed positions (1-based) are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
        return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    books.sort(key=custom_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted books
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in books]
    
    # Print the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":

Round_0.code:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a tuple of characters with the custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (ord(title[i]) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(title[i]))
            for i in range(m)
        )
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple where odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending and even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index

    # Extract the indices of the sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in indexed_titles]

Round_0.code:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    def custom_key(title):
        # Create a tuple of characters with odd positions as is and even positions negated
        return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_key(x[1]))
    
    # Extract the sorted indices
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def custom_sort_key(title):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(title)))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:n+2]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom sort key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

    # Create a tuple where odd-indexed characters are sorted ascendingly

    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))

def main():
    import sys

    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])

prompt:
Andi and Budi were tasked with arranging their bookshelf containing n books. Each book is represented by a book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Your task is to sort the list of book titles in this new order and return the sorted list.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4
